While living there, I traveled to Machu Picchu, the wondrous Incan ruins which were built on a bluff high up in the Peruvian Andes. I met a Japanese archeologist in a small village near the great ruins. He told me he was going to prove that his ancestors had sailed the Pacific and come to Peru many centuries ago. He was convinced they had established a great civilization in the jungles and ultimately came through the high Andes pass beyond the village and built Machu Picchu as a fortress against their enemies.The Japanese archeologist was just one of many people who believe that ancient civilizations are hidden in the impenetrable jungles of the Amazon. The stories are never-ending. El Dorado, the Cloud People of Peru, the earthworks of Western Amazonia, the Lost City of Z. . .Before I went to Lima, I had spent many weeks in a dugout canoe on the Rio Napo, a tributary of the Amazon that begins in the Ecuadorean Andes. The Amazon was so hostile we spent most of our waking hours battling it. No-see-ums and mosquitoes bombarded us day and night. Poisonous snakes and insects were a constant threat. When it rained, it came down in sheets so heavy it was impossible to see five feet in front of you. Huge logs crashed down from the Andes and threatened to crush our canoe. It would take hours to light a fire, the land was so wet.The jungles were so dense and hostile I was certain that the only way to travel was by water and the only places to live were along the hundreds of waterways that tumbled out of the mountains. I was also certain that the people who lived there centuries ago would be so busy fighting the elements they couldn’t possibly have the time or the will to create an advanced civilization. So I started reading The Lost City of Z with my own prejudices. Early in the twentieth century the English explorer Percy Harrison Fawcett regaled the world with his stories about his efforts to find Z, the fabled city that was supposedly built in the middle of the Brazilian jungles many hundreds of years ago . Some eighty years later, David Grann wrote this fascinating book about Fawcett’s adventures.The book is actually two stories. The first is about Colonel Fawcett, who spent much of his life exploring the Amazon searching for Z. Fawcett made six forays into the Bolivian and Brazilian Amazon between 1906 and 1914. Each time he returned to New York or London, he wrote and lectured extensively about his adventures. By the time he made his last trip in 1925, he was world famous, and so was the legend of Z. The second story, which is interwoven with Fawcett’s, is about the adventures of David Grann, the American journalist who wrote this fascinating book. review: A friend who knew that I had spent a month on the Amazon in a dugout canoe gave me Joe Kane’s book, ‘Running the Amazon’. It’s the story of the first A friend who knew that I had spent a month on the Amazon in a dugout canoe gave me Joe Kane’s book, ‘Running the Amazon’. It’s the story of the first expedition to travel from the source of the great river — 17,000 feet up in the Andes — to its mouth 4,200 miles away in Brazil. I began reading it with a huge dollop of skepticism. After all, I knew it wasn’t as romantic as it seemed. I had spent much of my time on the river swatting no-see-ums during the day, being devoured by mosquitoes at night, sometimes paddling for a full day in the blazing heat without seeing another human being, the river so wide at times you can barely see the other side. But I also knew that when you have a group of people bound together under difficult conditions, especially people with outsized egos, sparks can fly. The conditions for Kane and the nine others in the expedition he joined as its chronicler were difficult beyond imagination, far beyond my limited sea-level knowledge of the river. They had to battle oxygen deprivation at the top, rapids that roared through immense canyons on the way down, Peruvian revolutionaries who threatened to kill them, drug traffickers, unimaginable fatigue, the vagaries of nature, and most of all, their own emotions and those of each person on the expedition. The result: one of the most thrilling true adventure tales you can imagine.Joe Kane is a wonderful writer, and he had a unique cast of characters to write about. Imagine ten people with egos big enough to take a journey that no human being had ever taken before, one that would be dangerous at best and deadly at worst. This is the cast of characters that make ‘Running the Amazon’ such a magnificent tale. Kane, the only North American, is a newspaper reporter from San Francisco. Francois Odendaal, the South African expedition leader, is a man with grandiose plans and more than a few character flaws. Piotr Chmielinski, the Polish co-leader, proves to be a pillar of strength for a group that is torn by dissension before a third of the journey is completed. British doctor Kate Durrant, the only woman, provides medical support for the group. The others — Tim Biggs, Zbyszek Bzdak, Jack Jourgensen, Jerome Truran, Sergio Leon and Pierre Van Heerden — all have skills that should have made the expedition stronger. But egos clash and personal agendas get in the way. Only a handful would be around at the end of the six month journey. But they give us one helluva ride along the way....more

This roman a clef begins in 1977, as CIA agent Tom Miller reminisces about the 26 years he spent in the agency until new director Stansfield Turner summarily canned him and 800 other agents. Most of the characters in The Old Spook are real people involved in real mid-Twentieth Century political intrigues. The action begins in 1954, with Miller’s first job as part of the CIA team that orchestrated the overthrow of Guatemalan president Jacobo Arbenz. After Arbenz is ousted, Miller moves on to Mexico’s National University, where he poses as a researcher from Tulane so he can infiltrate the growing leftist movement in Mexico. Tom Miller spends much of his career being bounced around from one Latin American hot potato to another, including the CIA’s attempt to have the Mafia assassinate Castro, the ill-fated Bay of Pigs invasion, the downfall of Salvador Allende and the brutal dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet in Chile. Ironically, though, for all the Big Stage projects in Miller’s career, his life doesn’t get really exciting until he leaves the CIA. In 1978, he moves back to Milwaukee, where he grew up, and begins working as a private detective. He’s hired to find Jack Aldo, a guy who disappeared without a trace. As fate would have it, he unwittingly gets entangled in some unfinished business the CIA has with the Mafia. The more he looks into the mysterious disappearance of Aldo, the more danger he encounters. It’s the story of how two families in present-day Colombia were affected by the vicious war drug lord Pablo Escobar fought with the Colombian government in the mid-1980s and early 1990s. The story begins with young law professor Antonio Yammara’s recollection of Ricardo Laverde, a friend who we eventually learn was murdered as the two of them walked on a Bogota street. For years, Yammara is too taken with his own pain — you see, he was an accidental victim of the murderer’s bullets — to wonder why Laverde was murdered. It isn’t until 2009 that he begins to look into the reasons, and when he does, he takes us on quite an odd, fascinating journey.With this book, Juan Gabriel Vasquez shows us that he has the makings of a major literary talent, but his style and intent are far different than that other major Colombian literary talent, Gabriel Garcia Marquez. He does so beautifully, with exquisite control, revealing just enough of the unraveling mystery behind Laverde’s murder to lead one New York Times critic to call the book a page-turner, a label I wouldn’t give it. As beautifully written as the book is, it suffers from literary ennui, perhaps like the ennui Colombia seems to have suffered following Escobar’s takedown. All the major characters are troubled. Yammara, the protagonist, is an intelligent man with a prestigious job, a loving wife and a healthy baby girl. But he’s so depressed he’s depressing; he takes years to get over the gunshot wound he received when Laverde was murdered. When he does recover, he’s unappreciative of and insensitive to his wife and child. He’s not a sympathetic character. Laverde, whose life is looked at by Yammara years after he dies, is a more sympathetic, but equally troubled, character. But Laverde, we learn, has reasons to be troubled. Maya, his daughter, who Yammara tracks down in his effort to find out why Laverde was murdered, seems to glide through life as if she’s lost in a fog. They write themselves. Such is the Kafkaesque tale of Abdulrahman Zeitoun, a New Orleans painting contractor who stayed in the city during Katrina to protect his home and experienced twenty three days of unimaginable duress and, ultimately, injustice. The story, as told by Dave Eggers with an unemotional journalist’s eye, follows Zeitoun through the early hours of the storm, as windows blew out, branches crashed on the roof, and the house moaned in agony. As the eye of the storm got closer, he dragged his second hand canoe from the garage, just in case the city flooded. When the worst of the storm had passed, he looked at the house and felt it could have been much worse. By afternoon, the flood water, which had risen to eighteen inches, was almost gone. He called his wife, who had taken their four kids and dog to her brother’s house in Baton Rouge. “Come back,” he said. Fortunately, she decided to wait until the next day. The next day, the levees broke, and New Orleans was under water again, but this time the water didn’t stop rising until it reached the rooftops. Most of New Orleans, you see, is below sea level. Zeitoun thanked Allah he had his canoe. Over the next seven days, as the city lie under water, Zeitoun roamed the flooded streets in his canoe, helping stranded people and dogs, looking for help from the few aid workers who seemed to be in the city, watching the fires burn all around the city, trying to avoid the murderous gangs that had taken over downtown. On the seventh day, as the water receded, when it seemed the worst was over, Zeitoun’s troubles only worsened….Zeitoun is a tale that could only happen in New Orleans, a city that lives on both sides of darkness and light. It’s at the same time one of the most tolerant and racist cities in the U.S. It’s a study in contradictions, filled with both art and ignorance. When I lived there thirty years ago, a friend knocked on my door one night with clothes torn and face bruised. She told me someone had tried to rape her. I called the police. Ten minutes later two young officers arrived. One of them took a statement from my friend, while the other nodded off on my living room couch. When my friend finished giving her statement, the two officers rose to go. “If it happens again, let us know,” one of them said as they walked out the door.If it happens again…Sadly, I don’t think much has changed in New Orleans since then. For all its charm and beauty, it’s a city that’s being consumed by its own lunacy. Zeitoun is only one small, heart-wrenching chapter in the city’s bizarre history. Her depiction of the French slave owners in Saint Domingue — present-day Haiti — is absolutely mind numbing. It shows how human beings can completely abandon morality in the name of economic gain. The way the plantation owners of 18th century Haiti treated their black slaves can only be compared to the way Hitler treated the Jews.Allende’s heroine, Tete, a beautiful slave who is raped by her master when she is only eleven, is an admirable woman, full of dignity and strength. When the Valmorain family escapes to Louisiana and Tete is given her freedom, he refuses to recognize the daughter he had with her. Valmorain is at the same time high-handed and weak. He’s terrorized by a she-devil of a second wife, unable to accept his legitimate son’s anti-slavery ideas and is so stubborn he betrays the people who should mean the most to him. This is not an uplifting book, and Allende’s broad-brush approach to her story often makes it difficult to relate to her characters. Seldom does she show you enough of the main players for you to empathize with them — or despise them. Most, even Zarite, are foils for Allende’s broader purpose — writing the history of slavery and its victims, first in Haiti, and ultimately in Louisiana.
